linkTarget.anchoringText: It is well established in the surfactant science literature that surfactants in water, having hydrophobic and hydrophilic (literally water hating and water loving) parts in the same molecule, tend to self-aggregate at or above the critical micelle concentration (CMC) to minimise the overall free energy of the system. As a result, a surfactant transitions through several highly ordered phases as its concentration is increased [10-13]. These structures range from individual spherical micelles, on the nanometer scale, to packed rod-like structures which are much larger, see Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Visualisation of surfactant micelle structures as a function of surfactant concentration or active matter

formatted-caption.caption-text: Visualisation of surfactant micelle structures as a function of surfactant concentration or active matter

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 2 shows a gel diagram example for a blend of surfactants, a 3:1 blend of a C12,13- 7PO-sulfate and a C20-24 internal olefin sulfonate, in water. The nature of the blend, whether it is visually a liquid, a flowable gel (discerned by tipping the container to see it flow), or a solid gel, can be seen by making up different concentrations of the blend at temperatures between 0°C and 90°C. For this system at ambient temperature (20°C), a liquid is present <37% AM (easy to handle), a flowable gel 37-52% AM (more difficult to handle), a solid gel 52-65% AM (practically impossible to handle) and a flowable gel phase is re-established >65%AM.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Gel diagram for a 3:1 blend of a C12,13- 7PO-sulfate and a C20-24 internal olefin sulfonate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gel diagram for a 3:1 blend of a C12,13- 7PO-sulfate and a C20-24 internal olefin sulfonate

linkTarget.anchoringText: As reference points to compare the viscosity behavior of surfactant concentrates, Figure 3 shows the viscosity as a function of shear rate of two common foods, liquid honey (a viscous liquid) and smooth peanut butter (a paste). Liquid honey is a useful reference for surfactant concentrates as it is a high viscosity liquid that is still pourable at ambient temperature (20-25°C), its viscosity being around 10,000 cP. In contrast, peanut butter is not pourable and its viscosity climbs to 100,000 cP at a shear rate of 10 s-1. Liquid honey is largely a Newtonian liquid3 whereas peanut butter is non-Newtonian. Shear rate dependency of viscosity of a surfactant concentrate is important as it determines how it should be handled in facilities, for mixing and diluting, and what equipment should be used.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity data for honey and peanut butter, at 20°C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate, as a reference for surfactant concentrates

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity data for honey and peanut butter, at 20°C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate, as a reference for surfactant concentrates

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 4a, 5a, and 6a show the viscosity with shear rate and temperature of three low AM (20-30%AM) surfactants, C20-24 IOS, C15-18 IOS and the AAS C12,13 -13PO-sulfate. All three concentrates are viscous liquids with viscosities <10,000 cP at 10 s-1 shear rate at ambient temperature, less than liquid honey. This illustrates why low AM concentrates are often supplied for small volume projects, single-well tests and small multi-well pilots [2, 3], as their beneficial handling behavior in smaller project facilities tends to outweigh the benefit of supplying a high AM concentrate with a lower shipping cost.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity of 20% and 73% AM C20-24 IOS at 20 and 60 °C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate. The term “w/mod” is used to designate the concentrate with a viscosity modifier, added during manufacture to reduce viscosity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity of 20% and 73% AM C20-24 IOS at 20 and 60 °C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate. The term “w/mod” is used to designate the concentrate with a viscosity modifier, added during manufacture to reduce viscosity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 4a, 5a, and 6a show the viscosity with shear rate and temperature of three low AM (20-30%AM) surfactants, C20-24 IOS, C15-18 IOS and the AAS C12,13 -13PO-sulfate. All three concentrates are viscous liquids with viscosities <10,000 cP at 10 s-1 shear rate at ambient temperature, less than liquid honey. This illustrates why low AM concentrates are often supplied for small volume projects, single-well tests and small multi-well pilots [2, 3], as their beneficial handling behavior in smaller project facilities tends to outweigh the benefit of supplying a high AM concentrate with a lower shipping cost.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity of 30%, 67% and 55% AM C15-18 IOS at 20 and 60 °C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity of 30%, 67% and 55% AM C15-18 IOS at 20 and 60 °C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 4a, 5a, and 6a show the viscosity with shear rate and temperature of three low AM (20-30%AM) surfactants, C20-24 IOS, C15-18 IOS and the AAS C12,13 -13PO-sulfate. All three concentrates are viscous liquids with viscosities <10,000 cP at 10 s-1 shear rate at ambient temperature, less than liquid honey. This illustrates why low AM concentrates are often supplied for small volume projects, single-well tests and small multi-well pilots [2, 3], as their beneficial handling behavior in smaller project facilities tends to outweigh the benefit of supplying a high AM concentrate with a lower shipping cost.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity of 28 and 75% C12,13 -13PO-sulfate at 20 °C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity of 28 and 75% C12,13 -13PO-sulfate at 20 °C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate

linkTarget.anchoringText: An example of an engineering approach being successfully applied to a paste-like HAM concentrate is for a 62% AM IOS surfactant blend supplied to a multi-well pilot in West Siberia, Russia, the scope of the pilot being described elsewhere [14]. Figure 7 shows the three steps to supply and mix/dilute the paste. In Step 1 the surfactant is manufactured hot (at >60 °C) and transported in 20 ton insulated tanktrucks to a drumming location to package the product (still hot and pourable) into 55-gallon (~180 kg) drums.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Transport of a high AM IOS paste by tank-truck to be drummed (Step 1), emptying the drums of paste (Step 2) and mixing into a water/co-solvent stream (Step 3)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Transport of a high AM IOS paste by tank-truck to be drummed (Step 1), emptying the drums of paste (Step 2) and mixing into a water/co-solvent stream (Step 3)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Mixing of the delivered surfactant concentrate in the large storage tank of a project facilities is highly advisable (and the norm) as it tends to physically separate over time. I t is important that the concentrate is fully homogeneous before it is diluted and mixed with other components. A visual, qualitative aid showing how to select the mixing equipment appropriate to the surfactant concentrate’s viscosity is shown in Figure 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Mixing methods appropriate to the viscosity with shear behavior of surfactant concentrates, and two extreme Cases. Note the Figure is intended to be illustrative (qualitative) and not quantitative

formatted-caption.caption-text: Mixing methods appropriate to the viscosity with shear behavior of surfactant concentrates, and two extreme Cases. Note the Figure is intended to be illustrative (qualitative) and not quantitative

linkTarget.anchoringText: An additional benefit of mixed surfactant systems, such as high%AM AAS/IOS blends, is that they typically result in lower viscosities than the standalone high AM IOS parent as they take on the more fluid behavior of the AAS component [5]. Figure 9 illustrates this with the viscosity data at 20 and 60°C for a 73% AM AAS/IOS blend consisting of a 3/1 mixture of C12-13 -7PO-sulfate / C20-24 IOS. The high AM blend at 20°C has a viscosity <10,000 cP across the 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate range which can be compared to the HAM C20-24 IOS component (Figure 4b) which has a viscosity >100,000 cP at 10 s-1 at 20°C.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity data for a 20% and 73% AM 3/1 AM blend of C12-13 -7PO-sulfate / C20-24 IOS at 20 and 60°C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate. The term “w/mod” means the high AM concentrate includes a viscosity modifier to reduce viscosity

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity data for a 20% and 73% AM 3/1 AM blend of C12-13 -7PO-sulfate / C20-24 IOS at 20 and 60°C and 1 to 100 s-1 shear rate. The term “w/mod” means the high AM concentrate includes a viscosity modifier to reduce viscosity

linkTarget.anchoringText: A laboratory example of a staged AM dilution of an 80% AM AAS (C12-13 -7PO-sulfate) at 20°C, without and with the use of a viscosity modifier, can be found in Figure 10. The experimental details are given in the Experimental section. The corresponding rheological data for the example without viscosity modifier are shown in Figure 11. As noted earlier, the 80% AM C12-13 -7PO-sulfate is a viscous liquid at 20°C (viscosity around 1,000 cP at 20°C and 10 s-1) and is pourable.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Staged AM dilution of an 80% AM C12-13 -7PO-sulfate viscous liquid at 20 °C, without and with use of a viscosity modifier. Gels were observed during dilution which can be seen by inversion of the containers (a strong gel at 40% AM). The white, cylindrical ceramic beads utilized as a mixing aid can be seen in some of the samples

formatted-caption.caption-text: Staged AM dilution of an 80% AM C12-13 -7PO-sulfate viscous liquid at 20 °C, without and with use of a viscosity modifier. Gels were observed during dilution which can be seen by inversion of the containers (a strong gel at 40% AM). The white, cylindrical ceramic beads utilized as a mixing aid can be seen in some of the samples

linkTarget.anchoringText: A laboratory example of a staged AM dilution of an 80% AM AAS (C12-13 -7PO-sulfate) at 20°C, without and with the use of a viscosity modifier, can be found in Figure 10. The experimental details are given in the Experimental section. The corresponding rheological data for the example without viscosity modifier are shown in Figure 11. As noted earlier, the 80% AM C12-13 -7PO-sulfate is a viscous liquid at 20°C (viscosity around 1,000 cP at 20°C and 10 s-1) and is pourable.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Viscosity as a function of temperature (20, 40, and 60°C) and shear rate (1, 10, 100 s-1) during dilution of an 80% AM C12-13 -7PO-sulfate viscous liquid in 10% AM increments, without use of a viscosity modifier. The non-flowable gel is quite evident at 40% AM

formatted-caption.caption-text: Viscosity as a function of temperature (20, 40, and 60°C) and shear rate (1, 10, 100 s-1) during dilution of an 80% AM C12-13 -7PO-sulfate viscous liquid in 10% AM increments, without use of a viscosity modifier. The non-flowable gel is quite evident at 40% AM

linkTarget.anchoringText: One pair of scenarios (Figure 12) compares transport entirely by ISO-tank (20 ton) for low versus high %AM products for an EOR project destination in Middle East. This entails 19,000 km by sea and approximately 500 km by road/rail. In addition, Figure 12 compares transport from USA (manufacturing location) to the final destination versus transport of the feedstock from USA to the country/region with final manufacture near the EOR project location and finished product transport to the field.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Estimated logistical costs to transport (in ISO-tanks) a low and high AM surfactant concentrate to an EOR field project in the Middle East, with final manufacture in USA vs in country/near EOR project location

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated logistical costs to transport (in ISO-tanks) a low and high AM surfactant concentrate to an EOR field project in the Middle East, with final manufacture in USA vs in country/near EOR project location

linkTarget.anchoringText: Another pair of scenarios (Figure 13) considers shipment mostly via marine tank (1-1.5 kton parcel size) for the same options above.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Estimated logistical costs to transport (by bulk marine tank) a low and high AM surfactant concentrate to an EOR field project in the Middle East, with final manufacture in USA vs in country/near EOR project location

formatted-caption.caption-text: Estimated logistical costs to transport (by bulk marine tank) a low and high AM surfactant concentrate to an EOR field project in the Middle East, with final manufacture in USA vs in country/near EOR project location
